Dialogue.Stage Direction: Inside a space station hanging by a red giant star, six men dressed in white sit in recliners with their heads towards a central device with a globe on it. Very Alien. A monitor starts counting down in roman numerals, from XXX. One of the men is  Christopher Neame, who is dressed slightly differently from the others, and has a nasty scar down his right cheek. When the countdown finishes, his eyes open. Another count begins, this time going upwards. The other five men start jerking in their seats while our man gets up and goes to a wall panel, where he presses some buttons. The countdown reverses back up to XXX. The men stop jerking, and voices begin whispering. Eventually they become still. Our man walks to a control console and flicks some more switches. A male voice comes from the speakers.

Dialogue.Line: This is a recorded message. The Foundation for the Study for Advanced Sciences is under strict quarantine. Do not approach. Do not approach. Everything is under our control.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The man holds up his hand, and the sphere from the top of device rises into the air and glides into it. He leaves. The computer repeats its message as the man goes into the shuttlebay. Then the five remaining men jerk briefly and get up. They stagger around then fall down as a spaceship undocks and flies away.

Daniel Hill bicycles through Cambridge like any other student, on a bike with a wicker basket on the front, then puts it into a stand outside a college entrance and walks through to the quad. He checks a piece of paper then stops a student.

Dialogue.Line: Excuse me.
Yeah?
Do you know where P14 is?
Yes, it's over there, okay?
Thanks.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He heads off across the inner yard flagstones to the Don's climber-covered residential block.

A white-haired and bearded Professor wearing a black academic gown is unpacking a briefcase. He unwinds his scarf and removes the gown to reveal a slightly tatty jacket underneath. His study is lined from floor to ceiling with bookshelves, and the tables are also loaded with volumes. A police telephone box sits somewhat out of place amongst it all. The Professor looks at it, then goes and draws his curtains. There is a knock at the door.

Dialogue.Line: Come in.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Parsons enters. Chronotis does not look to see who it is, but heads off to the kitchen.

Dialogue.Line: Excuse the muddle. Creative disarray, you know.
Professor Chronotis?
Tea?
Oh, thanks.
Just put the kettle on.
Er, Professor Chronotis, I don't know if you remember me. We met at a faculty party a few weeks ago. It's Chris Parsons.
Oh yes, of course. Enjoy these faculty dos, do you?
Well, you know, it's
A lot of boring old dons talking away at each other, who never listen to a word anybody else says.
No, well, you said that
Talk, talk, talk. Never listen.
No, well, er, look, I hope I'm not taking up any of your valuable
Time? Oh no. When you get to my age, you'll find that time doesn't matter too much. Not that I expect you'll get to my age.
Oh, really?
Oh, yes. I remember talking to the last Master of College but one, or was it the last Master but two? Could have been three.
Three?
Yes, nice young chap. Died rather tragically at the age of oh. Run over by a coach and pair.
What was it you said to him?
Oh, I don't know. Long time ago, you know.
Yes. Professor, when we met you were kind enough to say that if I dropped round you would lend me some of your books on carbon dating.
Oh yes, of course. Happy to. Ah, there's the kettle.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chronitis disappears into the kitchen.

Dialogue.Line: Professor?
You'll find the books you want at the far end of this bookshelf. Third shelf down.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He goes back into the kitchen.

Dialogue.Line: Thanks.
Or is it the second shelf down? Second, I think. Anyway, take what you want. Milk?
Oh, yes please.
One lump or two?
Two please.
Sugar?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chronotis enters with two china cups of tea on a tray.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, here we are.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Parsons tucks his three selected books under his arm and looks at his wrist watch.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, actually Professor, I've just realised I'm going to be really late for a seminar. Look, I'm terribly sorry. Look, I'll bring these back to you next week, all right?
Yes, of course. Goodbye.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chronotis takes his newly purchased slim paperback out of its plastic bag.

Dialogue.Line: Goodbye. Actually, Professor, could I just ask you, where did you get that?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He points to the Tardis.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, I don't know. I think someone must have left it there when I was out.
Yes, well, I'll bring these back as soon as I can.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Parsons leaves. Chronotis settles down to read his Pan paperback copy of The Time Machine by H. G. Wells.
The Doctor is punting Romana along The Backs. She is reading a book.

Dialogue.Line: Wordsworth, Rutherford, Christopher Smart, Andrew Marvel, Judge Jefferies, Owen Chadwick.
Who?
Owen Chadwick. Oh, yes. Some of the greatest labourers in the history of Earth have thought here.
Newton, of course.
Oh, definitely Newton.
For every action, there is a equal and opposite reaction.
That's right.
So Newton invented punting.
Oh, yes. There was no limit to Isaac's genius.
Isn't it wonderful how something so primitive can be so
Restful?
No, simple. You just push in one direction and the boat goes in the other. Oh, I do love the spring. All the leaves, the colours.
It's October.
I thought that you said we were coming here for May week.
I did. May week's in June.
I'm confused.
So was the Tardis.
Oh, I do love the autumn. All the leaves, the colours.
Yes. Well, at least with something as simple as a punt nothing can go wrong. No coordinates, no dimensional stabilisers, nothing. Just the water, a punt, a strong pair of hands and the pole.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Whereupon the pole gets stuck in the mud of the riverbed and the Doctor has to let it go. They drift on under a bridge.

Dialogue.Line: The pole.
Er, I think it's about time that we go and see if the Professor is back in his room. Ask me how.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The man from the spacestation watches them drift under the bridge. He has a large carpet bag with him, and has acquired a large white hat and cloak to complete a Renaissance look.

Dialogue.Line: How?
For every reaction there is an opposite and equally different action.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The whisper of many voices is briefly heard before he walks away.

Dialogue.Line: Did you just heard voices?
What?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor has found a paddle.

Parsons places one of the books on top of two others - Hypnosis And The Law and Zaphod: My Stories. It slides off them onto the table. He opens it to discover it is written in an alien script. The time on the clock flies back and forth as he riffles through the pages, ending up where it started when he closes the book. He sniffs the book, then feels the cover and opens it. But when he reaches for a magnifying glass it snaps itself shut again. He tries stabbing it with a scalpel, but it moves out of the way of the blade.

Dialogue.Line: (still carrying the paddle) Here we are, St. Cedd's College, Cambridge. Founded in the year something or other, by someone someone in honour of someone someone someone. In honour of someone who's name escapes me completely.
Saint Cedd?
Do you know I think you're very probably right. You should have been an historian.
I am an historian.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor goes over to the college porter, who is putting notices up on a board on an easel.

Dialogue.Line: Good afternoon, Wilkin.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Yaroo, everybody. It's  Gerald Campion, the original TV Billy Bunter.

Dialogue.Line: Good afternoon, Doctor.
Wilkin! You remembered me.
Why, yes, of course, sir. An honorary degree in 1960.
Yes, but how kind of you to remember me.
That's my job, sir.
And you do it splendidly. Now
Professor Chronotis, sir? He returned to his room a few minutes ago.
Oh good, good, good. Wilkin, how did you know I wanted to speak to Professor Chronotis?
Because that's who you asked for when you were here in 1964, 1960 and 1955, sir.
Did I really? I was here in 1958.
Were you, sir?
Yes, but in a different body.
(laughs) Yes, sir.
Come along, Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor hands Wilkin the punt paddle.

Dialogue.Line: Nice to meet you, Wilkin. Bye, bye. (to Romana) Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Professor throws his book onto a table and gets up. There is a knock at the door.

Dialogue.Line: Come in.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chronotis goes into the kitchen. The Doctor and Romana enter.

Dialogue.Line: Come in. Over there. He'll ask us if we want tea.
Tea?
Yes, please. Two cups.
Milk?
Yes, please.
One lump or two?
Two please, and two sugars.
Oh, Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chronotis comes out with the tray.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, Doctor! How splendid to see you.
You too, Professor. This is Romana.
Oh, delighted, delighted. I've heard so much about you.
Have you really?
Well, not yet, but I will have done. When Time Lords get to my age they tend to get their tenses muddled up. Would you liked some biscuits too?
Well, I wouldn't have said no.
Crackers?
Oh, sometimes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The spaceman walks through Cambridge with his whispering carpet bag. A little later, tea and biscuits are being enjoyed.

Dialogue.Line: Three hundred years?
Yes, my dear.
And in the same set of rooms?
Ever since I retired from Gallifrey.
Didn't anybody notice?
One of the delights of the older Cambridge colleges. Everyone is so discreet. Now Doctor, young fellow, what can I do for you?
What can you do for me? You mean what can I do for you? You sent for me.
Sent for you?
Yes, we got your signal.
Signal? What signal?
Romana, didn't we get a signal from the Professor, would we come as soon as possible?
Yes. We come straight away.
I never sent you a signal, but it's very splendid to see you. Have another cracker.
I will. Professor, if you didn't send a signal, who did, hmm?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The spaceman marches through the arch and calls to the porter without looking at him.

Dialogue.Line: You! You!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Wilkin finishes putting a notice on the board and walks over.

Dialogue.Line: Were you addressing me?
I want Chronotis.
Professor Chronotis.
Where is he?
He will not wish to be disturbed. He is with the Doctor. A very old, a very old friend.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Skagra leaves the college.
More tea is about to be poured.

Dialogue.Line: Wait.
What for?
I've had an idea who sent that message.
Who?
Me.
I thought you said you didn't.
Yes, I know. Memory's getting a bit touchy of late. Doesn't like to be prodded about too much. But my dear old things, it must be ages since I send it.
I told you you'd got the time wrong, Doctor.
Yes, but you're always saying that.
You're always getting the time wrong.
Professor?
Yes?
What was it about, Professor?
What was what about?
The message?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chronotis comes out of the kitchen with a fresh pot of tea.

Dialogue.Line: I don't know. You've seen it more recently than I have.
Was it to do with the voices?
What voices?
Well, when I was on the river I heard a strange babble of inhuman voices, didn't you, Romana?
Yes.
Oh, undergraduates talking to each other, I expect. I've trying to have it banned.
No, no, no, no. It wasn't like that at all. It was the sound of humans, or, or ghosts, very quietly
Screaming.
Yes.
Overwrought imaginings, Doctor. No, I remember what it was.
What?
Delicate matter, slightly. It, it was about a book.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Parsons frowns at the book and puts it into a x-ray scanner compartment set into the wall. The scanner explodes. The book is too hot to touch, but otherwise intact. Parsons leave it alone, and it starts to glow and wibble slightly.

Skagra walks down St Edwards Passage and comes out between a clothiers and a camera shop, where a car is parked. He looks through the shop window until the driver leaves the shop and returns to his car, then approaches him.

Dialogue.Line: I say.
Yes? Can I help you?
Yes, perhaps you can.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: We don't hear the conversation, but the man lets Skagra get into the car with him and they drive away. Suddenly the car screeches to a halt in the middle of King's Parade. We next see it driving past St Cedd's with Skagra in the driving seat.
Chronotis is handing Romana a pile of books when he stops.

Dialogue.Line: Did you just hear voices?
Professor, I think that. I just heard voices. Romana, did you just hear voices?
Yes, very faint this time.
Anything to do with that book, Professor?
What? Oh, no, no, no. That's just a book I accidentally bought back with me from Gallifrey.
From Gallifrey? You brought a book from Gallifrey to Cambridge?
Well, just a few knick-knacks. You know how I love my books, Doctor.
Professor, you said you brought it back by accident.
An oversight. I overlooked the fact that I had decided to bring it. Just for study, you know. And as I'm now getting very old...
You thought that perhaps I'd take it straight back to Gallifrey for you.
Well, as I'm retired, I'm not allowed to have a Tardis.
Professor, I don't want to be critical but I will. It's very risky bringing books back from Gallifrey.
Is it?
I mean, they could be so dangerous in the wrong hands, hmm?

Clare, hi. Yes, it's me. What? Yes, I'm fine. Listen, the most amazing... Well, just stop being busy. This is important. There's this book, and it's got a molecular structure unlike anything I've ever seen before. Yes, I said book. It's like nothing on Earth. Extraterrestrial. No, I'm not mad. Listen, I've done everything. X-rays, microscope, you name it. Look, you don't have to believe everything till you've seen it yourself. Yeah, come on over. No, not in two hours. Now. Great.
(reads) On some nights, New York was as hot as Bangkok. (The Victim.) I've read that.
Hmm. Saul Bellow.
Once upon a time. Read that. And ah. Ah ha. And in the ancient days of Rassilon, five great principles were laid down. Can you remember what they were, my children?
It's just a Gallifreyan Nursery Book.
I know it is. It's very good.
I had it when I was a Time tot.
Yes, it is good.
Oh, that's just a memento. Not the right book at all. Where is it? Is this the one? Oh dear, no. No, I know it's here somewhere.
Professor? Professor? How many books did you bring back, for heaven's sake?
Just the odd two or seven, but there was only one that was in any way
Dangerous?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Skagra drives through Grantchester and parks the car before walking through a gate into a large field. Then he walks up an invisible ramp and disappears into the belly of an invisible spaceship.

Dialogue.Line: What does it look like? What's it called?
The Worshipful And Ancient Law Of Gallifrey.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor drops the large old tome he is holding.

Dialogue.Line: The Worshipful And Ancient Law Of Gallifrey?
Yes. Red book, about five by seven.
Professor, how did that book get out of the Panopticon Archives?
Well, what I did you see was I, I just took it.
Took it?
Yes. There's no one interested in ancient history on Gallifrey any longer, and I thought that certain things would be safer with me.
And were they?
Yes, in principle.
Excuse me. Delicate matter, Professor, slightly.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor lifts Chronotis down off his library steps.

Dialogue.Line: That book dates back to the days of Rassilon.
Does it? Yes, indeed.
It's one of the artefacts.
Is it, indeed.
Professor, you know that perfectly well. Rassilon had powers and secrets that even we don't fully understand. You've no idea what might have been hidden in that book.
Well, there's no chance of anyone else understanding it then, is there?
I only hope you're right, but we'd better find it. Romana?
Yes?
Little red book.
Five by seven.
Good, good.
Could be green.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The book search comes to an end.

Dialogue.Line: Roget's Thesaurus.
British Book of Bird Life, in colour.
Alternative Betelgeuse.
Time Machine.
Wuthering Heights.
(reads) Tandoori Chicken for starters?
Sweeney Todd.
Yes, but there's no sign of the Worshipful and Ancient Law of Gallifrey.
Do you really think it's important?
Of course it is. It's one of the artefacts.
Other than its historical value.
Yes, yes. Each of the artefacts was imbued with stupendous power. The meaning of most of them has been lost by now, but the powers remain, and the rituals.
I just mouthed the words like everybody else.
What words?

At the Time Academy Induction Ceremony. You know, I swear to protect the ancient law of Gallifrey with all my might and main, and will to the end of my days with justice and with honour temper my actions and my thoughts.
Yes. Pompous lot. All words and no actions.
Well, that's not true. What about Salyavin?
Salyavin?
Mmm.
Oh yes, Salyavin. He was a boyhood hero of mine.
Really, Doctor? A great criminal your hero?
Well, a criminal, yes, but he had such style, such flair, such
Panache?
Yes, yes. He was a bit like me in that respect.
Did you ever meet him?
I certainly did not!
All right.
He was imprisoned before I was born.
Where?
On... Do you know, I can't remember. Professor?
Yes?
Salyavin. He was a contemporary of yours, wasn't he? Where was he imprisoned?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chronotis runs in from the kitchen.

Dialogue.Line: I've just remembered.
I've only just asked you.
What?
Where Salyavin was imprisoned..
Salyavin? I'm not talking about Salyavin. Good riddance to him. We must find the book.
Professor, what do you think we're doing?
I just remembered.
What?
There was a young man here earlier. Came to borrow some books. He might have taken it while I was out in the kitchen making tea.
What was his name, Professor? What was his name?
Oh, if only I could remember. Oh dear, I've got a memory like a. Oh dear, what is it I've got a memory like? What's that thing you strain rice with?
What was his name, Professor?
Was he old? Young? Tall? Short?
I remember!
What?
A sieve! That's what it is. I've got a memory like a sieve.
Professor, what was his name?
Oh, I can't remember his name.
Oh, do please try.
A. A. No, it doesn't begin with A. B? B? B? BB DOCTOR + ROMANA: C?
D?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Clare lowers the book.

Dialogue.Line: What's it called?
Called? How should I know? Keightley, this book.
Clare.
This book will do for science what the Japanese did to Pearl Harbour.
What, bomb it?
What?
Feels like paper, it smells like paper, doesn't behave like paper. Plastic.
Not a single polymer in sight.
Metal?
No crystalline structure.
A single crystal, then.
Well, if it is, our mystery Don's got a lot of explaining to do. Half of it's stable all of the time, half of it none of the time. There's absolutely no way of telling what it's made of.
X-ray tomography.
Oh yeah, I got a positive result on the x-ray.
What?
It blew up. Not only can't I tell what the structure is, it actually doesn't seem to have a structure. Pure matter. Non-atomic matter.
You can't have matter without atomic structure. It's fundamental.
I can't explain it.
What's it about?
What?
The book, Chris. What is it about?
Well, I don't know, do I? It reads like a cross between Chinese and algebra.
Why don't you ask old What's-his-name?
Chronotis? Well, yes, that's the obvious thing to do, I suppose.
Is that why you haven't done it yet?
Make yourself at home, Keightley. (leaves)
It's Clare.
P. Q. R. X! X! Y?
Young!
Yes! Young Parsons. Born 1956, graduated 1978, honours degree in chemistry. Currently engaged in sigma particles.
Where would he be now, Professor?
Physics Lab, I should think. First left!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chronotis goes into the kitchen.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, yes, I'll be back in two minutes. (to Romana) If I'm not back in two hours, you and the Professor lock yourselves in the Tardis, send out an all-frequency alert, and wait. Wait!
Right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor leaves.

Dialogue.Line: More tea, my dear?
Lovely. Two lumps, no sugar.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Skagra leaves his invisible spaceship wearing the clothes of the car driver and carrying his carpet bag. The Doctor has appropriated some poor student's bicycle, and pedals through the streets to the accompaniment of squealing car brakes. Parsons is also bicycling back to the college, and nearly collides with the Doctor at the junction of Botolph Lane and Trumpington Street.
Skagra meets Wilkin walking through a quad.

Dialogue.Line: Is the Professor alone now?
Oh yes, sir. The Doctor left a few minutes ago.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Romana is toasting muffins on Chronotis' electric fire.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, dear.
What's the matter?
We've run out of milk.
Oh, I should think that's the least of our problems.
I do feel so stupid losing that book.
Don't worry, we'll find it.
I hope so. I do hope so.
Brr.
You're shivering. Are you cold?
No, it's just a feeling. Those voices unnerved me.
A cup of hot tea will do you good. Ah, no milk. I'll just pop out and get some.
I don't think that's a very awfully good idea, Professor.
Why not? It's the only way I know of getting milk, short of having a cow.
We've got plenty.
Oh, splendid. Type 40, isn't it? Yes, came out when I was a boy. That shows you how old I am.
I shan't be a moment.
Oh yes, you will. The kitchens are too far from the control chamber.
I've never known the Doctor use them anyway.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Romana goes into the Tardis.

Dialogue.Line: Salyavin! Good riddance to him, Salyavin. Good riddance. Bah. Undergraduates.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There is a knock on the door.

Dialogue.Line: Come in!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chronotis goes to the kitchen as Skagra enters.

Dialogue.Line: Only got lemon tea, I'm afraid. No milk. The girl's gone out to get some.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The voices fill the room.

Dialogue.Line: How many of there are you, for heaven sake? I've only got seven cups.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chronotis enters with seven cups on a tray.

Dialogue.Line: Professor Chronotis?
Where are the others?
Professor Chronotis.
Who are you?
I have come for the book.
Book? What book?
You know what book.
I don't know what you're talking about. I haven't got any books. That's to say, I've got plenty of books. What book would you like?
The book you took from the Panopticon Archives.
What do you know about the Panopticon?
The book, Professor. You are to give it to me.
On whose instructions?
Mine, Professor.
Who are you?
My name does not concern you. Give me the book.
I don't know where it is.
If you will not give me the information voluntarily, I will deduct it from you. I'm sure there is much else in your mind that will interest me.
Oh! No! No! (The sphere rises out of the carpet bag and fastens itself to Chronotis' forehead. His arms flail in pain and he falls to his knees.)
Do not fight it, Professor. Do not fight it, or you will die.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Clare is repairing the x-ray machine when she notices the shadow of someone entering.

Dialogue.Line: Hello.
Oh, hello.
You've just missed him, I'm afraid.
Sorry?
Chris Parsons? You've just missed him. Can I give him a message?
(pointing at the book) This isn't yours.
Er, no. Is it yours?
It belongs to some friends of mine.
Odd book.
Odd friends. And careless. Oddly careless. Why did you take it? CLARE: I didn't.
I know.
Look, what is this all about?
What's what about?
This book.
Have you read it?
No, I can't.
What, can't read?
No. I mean yes. I can read. I

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor puts the book to his ear.

Dialogue.Line: Where does it come from, what is it made of, and why did it make the x-ray machine explode?
It did that? CLARE: Yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He puts the book down.

Dialogue.Line: Hello, I'm the Doctor. And you?
Clare. Clare Keightley.
Clare Clare Keightley, can I have a look at your x-ray machine?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Skagra has gone, and Chronotis is lying on the floor when Romana comes out of the Tardis.

Dialogue.Line: I've got the milk. Professor? K9: Coming, Mistress.
Professor!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Romana checks Chronotis' vital signs, then there is a knock at the door.

Dialogue.Line: Who is it?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Parsons enters.

Dialogue.Line: It's me, Professor. I just came back to... What's happened? Is he all right?
I don't know. I think he's dead. K9: Negative, mistress. He is alive but he's in a deep coma.
What's happened to him? K9: Processing data.
Do you know him?
Hardly at all. He just lent me a book.
A book? We've been looking for a book. Chris Parsons?
Chris Parsons, yes.
Have you got it?
No. I left it back at the lab. You see I couldn't under
Isn't the Doctor with you?
Well, how would I know? I mean, how would I know the Professor was ill?
No, no, no. The Doctor.
What? K9: Mistress, the Professor has been subjected to psychoactive extraction.
Will he be all right? K9: Physical prognosis fair, psycho prognosis uncertain.
It's a robot!
Of course.
A robot dog.
Yes.
Neat.
K9, did you said psychoactive extraction? K9: Affirmative, mistress. Someone has stolen part of his mind.
What did your dog say? K9: Someone has stolen part of his mind. His attempts to resist have caused severe cerebral trauma. He is weakening fast.
Is this all for real?
Do you want to make yourself useful?
Well, if I can.
Go and get the medical kit from the Tardis.
The what?
Over there. First door on the left, down the corridor, second door on the right, down the corridor, third door on the left, down the corridor, fourth door on the right
Down the corridor?
No, white cupboard opposite the door, top shelf.
For a minute I thought you were pointing at that police box.
I was.
But
Please get it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Parsons enters the Tardis and immediately comes out again.

Dialogue.Line: But
Hurry up!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Parsons goes back into the Tardis. Romana uses books to make a pillow for Chronotis.

Dialogue.Line: Professor, can you hear me? Professor? Professor? K9: Mistress, his mind has gone.
You just said part of it, K9. K9: Affirmative. The part that is left is totally inert.
Professor! K9: No response, mistress.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Parsons comes out of the Tardis, out of breath, carrying a tool bag.

Dialogue.Line: Thank you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Romana fits a collar with a large circular piece on it around Chronotis' neck. It starts flashing green.

Dialogue.Line: What are you doing to him?
He's breathing and his hearts are beating, so his autonomic brain is functioning. This collar will take over those functions and leave his autonomic brain free.
What good'll that do?
He should be able to think with it.
Think with his autonomic brain? Don't be silly. The human brain doesn't work like that. The different function are separated by
The Professor isn't human.
Ah.
It had no detectable atomic structure.
Well, the book must have stored up vast amounts of subatomic energy and suddenly it released it when the machine was activated. Does anything strike you about that?
What?
It's a very strange way for a book to behave.
I would have thought that was obvious.
Never underestimate the obvious.
But what does it tell us?
Nothing, obviously.
Well?
So obviously it was meant to tell us nothing. Exactly the opposite function of a book. Therefore
It isn't a book. Then what is it?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A printer rattles.

Dialogue.Line: What was that?
Oh, should be the results of the carbon dating test I ran. (tears off printout) It's twenty thousand years old, Doctor!
Look at that.
A minus sign? Minus twenty thousand years?
Not only is this book not a book, but time is running backwards for it. I think I'd better return it as soon as possible, don't you?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Skagra snaps his fingers and summons the floating ball.

Dialogue.Line: Playback. SKAGRA [on screen]: The book, Professor. DOCTOR [on screen]: Was as hot as Bangkok. Once upon a time.
Trace memories.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chris Parsons muttering something.

Dialogue.Line: The collar's functioning. K9, is there any trace of conscious thought? K9: Processing data, mistress. Far too early to tell.
Good.
What do you mean, good?

Well, don't you see? When one works as a scientist, one doesn't always know where one's going, or that there is anywhere for one to go. That there aren't going to be big doors that stay permanently shut to one. But I look at all this, marvellous, and I know that a lot things that seem impossible are possible, so good. I take it that you...
Romana.
No, I mean that you're not from Earth. K9: Mistress, the Professor's condition is rapidly deteriorating.
Isn't there anything we can do? K9: Negative, mistress. The condition is terminal.
But is he thinking? Can he hear us? K9: Minimal cerebral impulses detectable, mistress.
Can he talk? K9: Negative. The speech centres of the brain are completely inoperative.
Well, your collar was a nice idea but
Shush.
What?
Wait a minute. K9, can you amplify his heart beat? K9: Affirmative, mistress.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two irregular heartbeats are heard.

Dialogue.Line: Brilliant!
What?
The Professor is a brave and clever man. Listen.
I don't understand.
He's beating his heart in Gallifreyan Morse. Professor, I can hear you. What do you want to tell us?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Thumpity thumpity.

Dialogue.Line: Beware. The. Sphere. Beware. Skagra. Beware. Shada. The. Secret. Is. In. The

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Silence.

Dialogue.Line: He is dying, mistress.
Professor! K9: All life function has now ceased, mistress. The Professor is dead.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is bicycling back to the College when he meets Skagra on a bridge, holding the sphere.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor?
Yes.
I am Skagra. I want the book.
Well, I'm the Doctor and you can't have it.
You attempt to hide it from me?
Yes. It'll be taken to a place of safety.
Where?
Oh, a little place I have in mind.
Doctor, you will give to me everything that you have in your mind. Your mind shall be mine.
I'm not mad about your tailor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The sphere floats towards the Doctor. He ducks under it and pedals off with it in pursuit.
The Tardis materialises nearby and the sphere retreats.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor!
Yes.
Shush. Hurry!
Coming.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor runs into the Tardis and it dematerialises with his scarf trapped in the doors.
Parsons bends over Chronotis, who vanishes.

Dialogue.Line: Professor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Tardis materialises, without the trapped scarf.

Dialogue.Line: Who are you?
Chris Parsons, Bristol Grammar School and Johns.
Never heard of you. You're the one causing all the trouble.
Me? Well, where's the book?
Where's the Professor?
Well, he just, just, just
He just what?
Well, I just don't know. His body just disappeared into thin air.
Where was the body?
There. It disappeared just before you arrived.
Here?
Yes.
It's gone. He must have been on his very last regeneration. Did you say someone had stolen his mind?
Yes.
That's funny. Skagra threatened to do that to me too.
Skagra?
You know the name?
Just before the Professor died, he said three things.
What?
Beware the sphere, beware Skagra.
And beware Shada.
Shada?
Do you know the name?
Shada. No. You?
Doesn't mean anything to me.
Well, Mister Skagra, or whatever it is you call yourself, you've killed a Time Lord and a very old friend of mine. It's time you and I had a little chat. K9! K9: Master?
K9, can you find any trace of that sphere? K9: Affirmative, Master, but it is far, far too weak to take a bearing.
We'll have to wait till it's active again. Now listen, K9, the moment the signal becomes clear K9: Affirmative, Master.
Good, good. Right, we'll wait in the Tardis.
Excellent thought.
Come on. You too, Bristol.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: By the river, in the pouring rain, an innocent fisherman gets his mind stolen by the sphere. He falls into the water where he presumably drowns.
Clare knocks on the door, which has lots of notices stuck to it.

Dialogue.Line: Hello?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Tardis dematerialises. Clare enters.

Dialogue.Line: Hello?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Tardis materialises, and the Doctor, Parsons and Romana come out just in time to see -

Dialogue.Line: There it is.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The sphere disappear into the invisible spaceship.

Dialogue.Line: Did you just see what I didn't see?
No.
Neither did I.
It just vanished.
That's what I said. Watch that cow pat.
Come on, K9. K9 [OC]: Coming, mistress.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Skagra is sitting cross-legged, with the book open in front of him, when the sphere starts beeping.

Dialogue.Line: Report.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A clip of the Doctor and Romana escaping into the Tardis.

Dialogue.Line: Continue.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: It shows the Tardis dematerialising.

Dialogue.Line: What is that machine?
It displays the characteristics of a Gallifreyan time capsule, my lord. Type 39, possibly type 40.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The display says - traces of artron energy, type 39/40, status: Obsolete.

Dialogue.Line: Present whereabouts?
It is currently in close proximity, my lord. Warning, my lord. Intruders are approaching the ship.
Show me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The screen shows the group walking across the field. The book glows briefly.

Dialogue.Line: Admit them.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor bumps into the spaceship with his nose.

Dialogue.Line: Ow! Don't move.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Every touch gives out an electric crackle and a hollow boom as the Doctor feels along the side of the invisible object.

Dialogue.Line: K9, there's something here. K9: Affirmative, Master.
Then why didn't you tell me, you stupid animal? K9: I assumed you could see it, master.
What is it, K9? K9: A spacecraft, mistress, of very advanced design. Many of its functions are beyond my capacity to analyse.
If I built something that clever I'd want people to see it.
Shush. K9, what's it powered by? K9: Insufficient data.
Aren't we all? Where does it come from? K9: Insufficient data.
What does it look like? K9: Very large, mistress.
How large? K9: One hundred metres long.
One hundred metres? That should keep the cows guessing. Hmm. There must be an entrance somewhere.
What's that carpet doing there?
Got to be an entrance. What's that carpet doing here?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A piece of red carpet is lying on the grass. Our trio reach the carpet, and the Doctor trips over something. There is a whirring sound as the ramp is lowered.

Dialogue.Line: A door is opening, Master.
Affirmative, K9, affirmative.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor walks up the ramp followed by Romana and, after a little hesitation, Parsons.

Dialogue.Line: Come along, K9, heel.
Affirmative, master.
Chris? Chris Parsons? Professor Chronotis?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Clare finds Parsons' satchel, and looks inside.

Dialogue.Line: Chris?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She looks at one of the books that was Chronotis' pillow, makes a decision and leaves quickly.

Dialogue.Line: Better than an old police box.
K9, any sign of that deranged billiard ball? K9: Master?
The gagglebat, the beastie.
The sphere, K9. K9: Negative, mistress.
Romana, I'd feel much happier if you three waited outside. No point in all of us walking into the spider's web.
I'll stay. You might need help.
Well, if it's... Er, okay.
I wonder if

Dialogue.Stage Direction: But a cube has appeared behind the Doctor and made his companions vanish.

Dialogue.Line: Romana?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Skagra enters the corridor behind him.

Dialogue.Line: They will not be harmed, Doctor. For the moment. These small party tricks are purely functional. Their purpose is precisely defined, as is mine.
Where have you taken them?
Come with me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Skagra places his hand on the sphere.

Dialogue.Line: Skagra, what have you done with the Professor's mind?
It is to be put to a more useful purpose.
It was serving a perfectly useful purpose where it was.
Not to me.
You realise he died.
Only his mind was of use to me, not his life.
You take a very proprietorial attitude to other people's brains.
It seems to me that the Time Lords take a very proprietorial view of the universe.
Just exactly who are you, Skagra?
That knowledge will be of no use to you.
Then you may as well tell me.
I may as well not. Besides, we have other matters to discuss. This book, Doctor.
Which book? This book?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Skagra hands it to the Doctor.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, I've read it. It's rubbish.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Skagra takes it back.

Dialogue.Line: Then perhaps you'd be good enough to read it to me.
Oh, I have a very monotonous reading voice. Really, by the time I'd got to the bottom of the first page you'd be asleep and I'd escape, and then where would you be?
Read it to me.
I presume you can't read Gallifreyan, then.
Like a native. Read it.
All right. Are you standing comfortably?
Yes.
Then I'll sit down.
Begin.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The sphere hovers by the Doctor's head.

Dialogue.Line: (unintelligible alien words) I'm paraphrasing, of course.
Doctor.
Shush, shush, shush. You'll like this bit. This is a good bit. (more silly sounds) Skagra, do you realise this book doesn't make one bit of sense.
A fool would realise it was written in code.
Skagra, this thing is written in code. How am I doing?
I believe you know the code.
Who, me?
Yes.
Oh no, no, no. I'm afraid I'm very stupid. Very stupid. I'm very, very stupid.
Doctor, I believe you, as a Time Lord, know this code, and you will give that knowledge to me.
There's no point in giving me orders. I'm very stupid.
It was not an order.
It wasn't?
It was a statement of fact.
Ah. How stupid of me.
You have no choice. You will give that knowledge to me.
Ah, well, I don't know about that. I don't know about anything. In fact I'm really an appallingly stupid creature. (laughs)
You will be.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The sphere goes to the Doctor, who screams.
Romana, K9 and Parsons are in a small square room with no doors or windows.

Dialogue.Line: There's no door. We must have got here by some sort of matter transference.
Very clever.
Oh, I suppose you do this sort of thing the whole time.
Yes, actually. K9, can't you pick up any trace of the Doctor? K9: Negative, mistress. Every signal is shielded.
I was meant to be delivering a paper to the Astronomical Society tonight.
Oh, yes?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Romana makes adjustments to K9's innards.

Dialogue.Line: Can you pick up anything now? K9: Negative, mistress.
Yes, I finally disproved the possibility of life on other planets.
Oh, yes?
Well, I can deliver at next month's.
Now try.
Have to be a complete re-write though. K9: Triple negative.
Curious substance, this wall.
Oh, blast it. K9: Please duck.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: K9 fires his laser, which ricochets several times.

Dialogue.Line: Apologies, mistress.
Not at all. K9: The wall is blast proof.
It was a good try, K9. K9: Mistress, I am now picking up faint signals.
What is it? Can you let us hear it? K9: Affirmative, mistress.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: It is the muttering voices.

Dialogue.Line: Sounds different this time. K9: A new voice has been added.
A new voice? K9: Affirmative. It is the Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Clare runs out of the building and straight into Wilkin.

Dialogue.Line: Oh!
Mind where you're going.
You don't know where Professor Chronotis has gone, do you?
Calm down. Isn't he in his room?
No, I've just come from there.
Well that's funny, he didn't come out this way. I'll tell you what. If you'd like to leave a message, I'll see he gets it.
Well look, it's terribly urgent. A book a friend of mine was taking to him, well, I think it's very dangerous.
Well what I say is people shouldn't write things if they don't want people to read them.
No, you don't understand. The book itself, it's atomically unstable. It seems to be absorbing radioactivity. I think it's very, very dangerous.
What, a book's doing that?
Yes. We must find the Professor.
All right, Miss, I'll tell you what. You go back to his room and I'll ring round the College and see if I can find out where he's got to.
Yes. But wait. Look, it's... All right, I'll go back.
I don't know. Nowadays they'll publish anything.
Are you positive, K9? Absolutely negative? K9: Affirmative. No signals on any frequency, mistress.
Oh, I wish I could get out of here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The cube of light appears and Romana vanishes.

Dialogue.Line: That's it! K9: Please explain.
That's what you have to say. I wish we could get out of here. I wish we could get out of here? Oh, I wish we could get out of here. Oh, blast. No! No, no, no, no, K9. No. Good dog.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Skagra, back in his white suit, leads Romana down the ramp.

Dialogue.Line: Where are you taking me? Where are you taking me?
Quiet! Or I'll use the sphere on you as well.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The sphere follows them down, and we hear the ramp close.

Dialogue.Line: How did she get out and not me? K9: Insufficient data.
Insufficient data. Insufficient data? Oh, why did I ever let myself get involved in this? K9: Insufficient data.
Where are you taking me?
Your travelling capsule.
If you think I'm going to open the door, you're going to be extremely disappointed.
It's just as well I have the Doctor's key.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Skagra unlocks the Tardis and pushes Romana inside.

Dialogue.Line: Ow!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Skagra follows, then the sphere. The key is still in the lock when the Tardis dematerialises.
Parsons stops pacing and squats by K9.

Dialogue.Line: Not a clue.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They are teleported away.

Clare starts a not very thorough search of the room. She finds a old key on the mantelpiece and uses it to unlock a cupboard underneath a bookcase. Behind the old cricket pad and tennis racket is an array of dusty machinery. She rests her hand on the bottom row of books and it turns round into a control panel. Clare flicks a switch and some lights come on, then the curtains close. She pulls a lever, there's a flash and she is thrown back across an occasional table as the room shimmers. Outside, Wilkins enters the doorway from the quad.
Wilkin knocks on the door.

Dialogue.Line: Miss? Are you in there, Miss?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Wilkin opens the door, but instead of the wood panelled rooms, a blue shimmering light greets him.

Dialogue.Line: Hey, we did it. K9: Danger, Doctor. Danger.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: K9 tried to laser open the door to the command deck, and fails. Parsons presses the top button and the doors open.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor!
Oxygen levels returning to normal.
Who said that?
I am the ship, and the servant of my lord Skagra.
Where's that voice coming from? K9: Master?
Don't worry, K9. He's all right.
No, I'm not. I'm dead.
Pardon?
I've been nearly too clever by three quarters.
You never seem to do anything by halves.
I persuaded the ship that I was dead, and it cut off my oxygen supply.
You what?
It won't take orders from an enemy of Skagra, but since it believes I'm dead, since I am dead, the ship has no reason not to accept my orders.
What?
It only resumed the oxygen supply when you came in. You're still alive. Officially.
That's reassuring.
Where's Romana?
I thought she was with you. Whatever took us off, came back for her.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor throws his bag of jelly babies across the room.

Dialogue.Line: Skagra! He must suffer. K9, is the Tardis still where we left her outside? K9: Negative, master.
What?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A big red and orange spaceship complete with landing deck. The Tardis materialises inside. The sphere leads Skagra and Romana out into a corridor.

Dialogue.Line: Where are we?
On my command ship.
And what are you hoping to command?
More than you can possibly imagine.
I have a very vivid imagination.
So have I.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Something approaches, viewing them through a red filter.

Dialogue.Line: Welcome back, my lord.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is playing with his yo-yo.

Dialogue.Line: So where's he taken your Tardis?
Or when.
What?
Time machine.
Ah, yes. He took Romana because she can operate it for him?
So can he. He's got a copy of my mind in that sphere of his. Everything I know is at his disposal.
Then why did he take her with him?
Well, probably wants someone to show off too.
There's one thing he doesn't know.
What?
You're still alive.
Shush, shush, shush, shush. I'm dead, remember.
(sotto) Doctor, why doesn't the ship know that?
(sotto) It's only programmed to obey instructions, not to think about them. Blind logic. It serves Skagra and doesn't think beyond that.
(sotto) Does it know where Skagra's gone?
Ship! Speaking to you as the late lamented enemy of your lord Skagra, I command you to tell me where he has gone.
I do not have that information.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Skagra snaps his fingers and the sphere settles on a pillar.

Dialogue.Line: Why don't you tell me? Why won't you just say what you're trying to do?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Skagra looks out of a big window.

Dialogue.Line: Tell me what you see.
Stars.
What are they doing?
Doing?
Yes.
Well, they're just there. They're
Exactly. Spinning uselessly through the void. And around them, billions of people spinning uselessly through their lives.
Says who?
I say.
And who are you?
What I am now is not important. But what I, what we all shall become...
What do you
Shush. Look.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He opens his hands.

Dialogue.Line: What?
What do you see?
Nothing.

Billions of atoms spinning at random, expending energy, running down, achieving nothing. Entrophy, like the stars. But what is the one thing that stands against entrophy, against random decay? Life. See how the atoms are arranged here? They have meaning, purpose. And what more meaning and purpose than in here. (his head) You do not understand me. Your mind is too limited. My Krargs. They shall be the servants of the new generation.
New generation? New people?
Not new people. A new person.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They enter a vapour-filled room.

Dialogue.Line: What?
Shush.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Skagra activates a machine, and a new Krarg is created. Giant shaggy alien red yeti with post-it notes instead of fur, pretty much.

Dialogue.Line: What is your command, O master?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is working inside some panelling.

Dialogue.Line: So it's back to square one, then.
That's it! Ow! Ouch!
What?

Square one. That's where we've got to go if we want to find out what Skagra's up to. Once we know that, we know where to find him. Ship, I order you to take us to where your lord Skagra last came before arriving here.
Your order does not conflict with my programmed instructions. I will activate launch procedures. Launch procedures activated. Launch procedures activated. Launch procedures activated.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Somewhere, more Krarg are created. Skagra's ship becomes visible once it is airborne and zooms off into space.

Dialogue.Line: Ship, how long will the journey take?
Thirty nine astro-siderial days.
What? That's neary three months.
At maximum drive. We have many hundreds of light years to cover.
Hundreds of light years in three months? That's incredible.
Yes, incredibly slow. Stop.
Repeat, please.
I said, stop. Halt. (Juddering halt knocks Parsons off his feet.)
Oh, what are you doing?
Ship, I'm now going to introduce you to a few new concepts. Now listen very carefully. Reverse the polarity of your main drive feed. Right?
Accomplished.
Regrade your de-ossilation diagetic synthesisers by ten points.
Warning. Drive will explode in twelve seconds. Eleven. Ten.
Did I say ten points? Sorry, minus ten points.
Accomplished.
Realign your maxivectal meter on drag so they cross-connect with your radial bicentric arrows.
Accomplished.
Good. Now, this is the easy bit.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: More Krargs emerge.

Dialogue.Line: What have you done?
I've constructed a primitive dimensional stabiliser by remote control. The journey will now only take a couple of minutes to anywhere.
Doctor, you are extremely ingenious, for a dead man.
Oh, well, let's not harp on that aspect too much, shall we?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A familiar sound is heard as the ship dematerialises.

Clare lies unconscious on the carpet as the lights on the control panel continue to blink. She starts to wake up, bumps her head on the underside of an occasional table, then gets up and sits on a chair. Chronotis pops up from behind the back of the chair next to her, wearing a nightcap and gown. Clare jumps out of her skin

Dialogue.Line: What have you done to my machine?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He switches off the console, and the vague background humming stops.

Dialogue.Line: Tea?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chronotis goes into the kitchen and comes straight out with the tea tray.

Dialogue.Line: May I ask who you are?
I was, I am, I will be, Professor Chronotis. Oh dear. We Gallifreyans have never managed to come up with a satisfactory form of grammar to cover these situations.
Look, I don't understand what's happening. What situation?
(sitting) Timelessness. Standing obliquely to the time fields.
Is that what we're doing?
Oh yes, and very grateful I am to you for arranging it.
Me? But all I did was just press a button and
Yes, I know. A very ancient Tardis, this. I rescued it literally from the scrap heaps. I'm not allowed have one really, you know. Still, just as well though, isn't it, otherwise I'd be dead still.
Still dead?
Oh, yes. Yes, I've been killed. Only your timely mishandling of this machine meant that you tangled with my time fields at the critical moment. You're not following me, are you?
Er, no.
Good. Think of me as a paradox in an anomaly and get on with your tea.
Oh, yes.
We must find Skagra.
Yes.
He has the book.
Ah!
You know about it?
Well, I sort of
It's a very dangerous book and I have been very careless. It is the key to Shada.
Oh.
The ancient prison planet of the Time Lords. They have been induced to forget about it.
I see.
If Skagra is meddling with mind transference, mind control, he's only going to Shada for one particular reason and it is imperative that he be stopped.
Yes! Er, why? What on Earth's there?
It's not a matter of what, it's a matter of who.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: An image of what the Doctor saw on the pages of the book is on a wall screen, projected by the sphere.

Dialogue.Line: What's so important about the book?
It is the Ancient Law of Gallifrey.
So?
So what does a Gallifreyan judge say when passing sentence?
Er, we but administer. You are imprisoned not by this court but by the power of the Law. It is not
The power of the Law. It used to be quite literally true.
What? You think that book is some sort of key to
The key with which the Time Lords used to imprison its most feared criminals. Criminals such as... He doesn't know. He doesn't know the code.
I'm glad you realised that. It's about time.
Time. Time. About time. Yes, of course. I should have seen that. A Gallifreyan code would have to include the dimension of Time. (to the sphere) Stop. Find me the Doctor's last reference to Time.
Oh, come on, ship. What's taking you so long?
Estimated docking time, two minutes.
Hurry up.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A Krarg appears in the doorway behind them.

Dialogue.Line: Who are you?
Doctor!
Ah, hello there.
(sotto) What is it?
(sotto) I don't know.
You are intruders.
Well actually, I'm dead, and this is Bristol.
Chris.
You trespass on my lord's ship. You shall die.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: K9 fires his laser.

Dialogue.Line: What on Earth is it?
What's Earth got to do with it? Looks like some sort of crystalline structure.
Preparing to dock.
You go ahead. Don't mind us.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The spacecraft materialises inside the shuttle bay.

Scenes.Scene: FSAS Space Station - outside the shuttlebay

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The place has gotten dark and dirty since we were last here. The Computer is still repeating the message from the top of the story.

Dialogue.Line: This is a recorded message. The Foundation for the Study of Advanced Sciences is under strict quarantine. Do not approach. Do not approach. Everything is under our control.
Where is this place? DOCTOR [OC] How should I know?
Big, isn't it?
I wonder where everybody's got to?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They come out of the shuttle bay.

Dialogue.Line: I don't know.
Neither do I.
And I don't believe that we travelled hundreds of light years.
Why not?
You cannot travel faster than light. Einstein.
What? Do you understand Einstein?
Yes.
What? And quantum theory?
Yes.
What? And Planck?
Yes.
What? And Newton?
Yes.
What? And Schoenberg?
Of course.
You've got a lot to unlearn. Ah.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor spots the letters IASS ASD on a plaque on the wall.

Dialogue.Line: Institute for Advanced Science Studies.
ASD Advanced State of Decay?
Shush.
What?
Shush. Did you hear something?
No.
Shush.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They enter the room from the first scene in the story.

Dialogue.Line: Ah ha! Think Tank. Quite interesting.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor turns off the broadcast.

Dialogue.Line: Quite interesting? This is fascinating. Absolutely fascinating. Do you mean to say that all this means something to you?
Oh yes! It's all terrible simple. You see, when ah!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Then they see the five remaining men huddled together, all terribly hairy and with very long nails now.
Skagra is reading the book as the time rotor goes up and down. Romana enters.

Dialogue.Line: Keep back.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The sphere pins her to the doors. She notices that the time rotor stops when Skagra ceases to turn pages. Then he notices it too.

Dialogue.Line: Exactly. Time runs backwards over the book. As I turn the pages within the time field of this machine, the machine operates. Turning the last page will take us to Shada.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Skagra hands Romana over to a Krarg.

Dialogue.Line: I have broken the code.
We can repair it, my lord.
Fool. Make all preparations for the entry into Shada. You are about to meet one of the greatest and most powerful criminals in all history.
Salyavin.
A man the Time Lords chose to forget.
Bristol?
Yes?
You still feeling marvellous?
Yes.
Right. Give me ten seconds.
What?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor goes round the back of Parsons to the cowering Think Tank. Parsons takes up a boxing pose.

Dialogue.Line: Well, come on then! Well, come on!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Krarg turns away from him and hits the sparkling pyramid.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor, it's going to blow up!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor stands in front of the scientists as the Krarg advances on them. Smoke starts to fill the room. Parsons runs behind the Krarg and out into the corridor, where he grabs a dangling power cable, then goes back in. K9 leaves. Parsons drags the Doctor out of the room.

Scenes.Scene: FSAS Space Station - outside the shuttlebay

Dialogue.Line: It's jammed!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Krarg attacks the scientists. The Doctor uses his sonic screwdriver, and the door rises. The Doctor, Parsons and K9 get underneath it just as the Krarg arrives on the scene. The door closes in front of it. The spacecraft dematerialises and the space station goes KaBOOM!!

Dialogue.Line: Good ship, good ship. Good, you're learning. Which is more than we're doing.
What do you mean?
Well, we're still no nearer to finding Skagra or Romana.
What do you think we should do?
I don't know.
Well, try looking on the bright side. At least we're
I am looking on the bright side, and it's dark, very dark. Now listen to me, ship. I'm going to ask you once again. Where is your lord Skagra?
He did not reveal his destination.
But you must have some idea?
I am a computer. I do not have ideas. I obey instructions.
So you've no idea where he's gone.
I do not.
Bah. Doesn't he have a home to go to?
Yes.
He has?
Correct.
Well, then why didn't you tell me?
I have orders not to.
But, will you please take us there?
The order conflicts with my programmed instructions.
Well, just you tell it not to worry. I'm sure your lord Skagra will be very anxious to pay his last respects to me.
I obey.
I do hate computers. They're so literal minded. Aren't you, K9? K9: Affirmative, master.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chronotis is dressed to go out, and he and Clare are working on components from his Tardis mechanism.

Dialogue.Line: Oh. Look, I don't even know what I'm meant to be doing.
We must get this old perambulator moving again.
Well, it certainly moved when I touched it.

Oh, a spasm, a mere spasm. I just hope it wasn't a dying spasm, because it has left us jammed between two irrational time interfaces. Time is moving away from us. If we do manage to disentangle ourselves, I'll just have to be careful, otherwise I shall cease to exist again.
Oh. Really?
Now do as I do.
What's that?
Forget about it.
Oh, Professor, that's easier said than done. Who is this, er, Salyavin person?
Salyavin? He was a criminal. His exploits have been wildly exaggerated. He was a hotheaded, brilliant young man with a peculiar talent. I can't fix this.
Can I help?

Difficult, very difficult. To repair an interfacial resonator requires two operations which must be performed absolutely simultaneously. And to be honest, my dear, I don't think you have the knowledge.
So we're stuck.
Yes.
Well, I can learn, you know. I'm very quick.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chronotis fetches a large wrench from the kitchen.

Dialogue.Line: What's the matter?
Listen to me. Listen to me very carefully. What I am about to do, you are never to speak of, and this is the only time I will ever do it.
What are you talking about?
Do I have your promise?
Well, what are you going to do to me?
Do I have your promise?
Yes, yes, all right.
What is that piece of equipment you have in your hand?
I have absolutely no idea.
Good.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chronotis puts down the wrench and takes off his spectacles. His eyes glow as he stares hard into Clare's eyes.

Dialogue.Line: Now, what is that piece of equipment?

This? Er, it's a conceptual geometer relay, with an agronomic trigger, a totally defunct field separator. But it doesn't matter. We can dispense with it if we can get that interfacial resonator working again.
Splendid!
Well, let's do that then, shall we?

Dialogue.Character: (The spacecraft materialises on the hangar deck right next to another identical spacecraft. Lots of Krarg are still being made here.) SKAGRA
Dialogue.Line: Well? KRARG: We have a full complement, my lord. SKAGRA: Good. Then we can begin.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Krarg leave. A finger taps Romana on the shoulder and she gasps.

Dialogue.Line: I wish you wouldn't do that.
How did you get here?
These kind people brought me.
Doctor.
Ah, hello there.
I am a little surprised to find you here.
Your ship was a little surprised
Oh, you stole my ship.
Only after you stole mine. Ah, there she is. I hope you've been looking after her. If you've been over-revving her...
I'm curious to know how you survived the attentions of my sphere.
Well, it only looks for what it expects to find. I made it look for the wrong things.
If you've come here in the hope of interfering with my great purpose.
Great purpose? Great purpose? Ha!
The very greatest purpose, Doctor.
You want to take over the universe, don't you. I've met your sort before. Any moment now a mad gleam will come into one of your eyes and you'll start shouting, the universe shall be mine.
How naive, Doctor. How pathetically limited your vision must be.
Limited?
Take over the universe? How childish. Who could possibly want to take over the universe?
Exactly. That's what I keep telling people. It's a troublesome place, difficult to administer. And as a piece of real estate, it's worthless, because by definition there'd be no one to sell it to.
Such visions are for infants. My purpose will fulfil the natural evolutionary goal of all life.
Oh yes?
With the aid of these spheres, I shall make the whole of creation merge into one single mind, one god-like entity.
You will?
The universe, Doctor, shall not, as you so crudely put it, be mine. The universe shall be me.
Ah. Have you discussed this with anyone? I mean, why don't you send one of your rocky pals off to make some tea and we can sit down and chew on a macaroon.
Doctor, your inane whitterings do not interest me. This will happen. It will start within hours. And once it has started, nothing you or anyone else can do will stop it. Take them away. They bore me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Krargs bear down. The Doctor taps one.

Dialogue.Line: Jink!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He grabs Parsons and runs.

Dialogue.Line: Kill them.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: K9 follows the Doctor, but Romana is held fast.

Dialogue.Line: What's a jink?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor, Parsons and K9 hide in an alcove as the Krarg lumber past.

Dialogue.Line: Clever jink that, don't you think? I made them think I was trying to get to the Tardis.
What were you trying to do?
Get to the Tardis.
Doctor, that man must be mad, mustn't he?
Oh, madness, sanity, it's all a matter of opinion.
And what's your opinion?
He's as mad as a hatter. They've gone. Right, back the way we came. Quietly.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Further on they hear a stuttering sound.

Dialogue.Line: Shush.
(sotto) What?
That.
Your Tardis. Surprised you can hear it from here.
There's something odd about it. Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A Krarg fires a bolt that just misses Parson's head.

Dialogue.Line: Run!
It's a dead end.
Then we're trapped.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A wooden door with a brass knob is against a wall.

Dialogue.Line: This wasn't here before.
Get in!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The door bursts open and the Doctor and Parsons run in from the Carrier corridor and slam it shut again. They quietly congratulate each other then turn to see where they are. Their jaws hit the floor with a loud Thud!

Dialogue.Line: Keightley!
Chris?
Cup of tea?
Tea? (Shortly afterwards, the chasing Krarg has moved off and the Doctor is sitting at the control panel.)
Doctor, how do you like my Tardis?
Oh, ace. Ace.
It's strictly unofficial. I'm not really allowed to have one.
Yes, and what better way to hide it than by living in it, you old sly boots.
What are you doing here?
How am I'm suppose to know. Yeah, and what's the Professor's room doing here?
Oh, you may well ask. But ask the Professor.
Doctor, where is Skagra?
Shush. Not so loud. He's just outside.
Oh.
He's got Romana, he's got the Tardis, he's got the book. I thought you were dead, Professor.
Yes, so did I.
Did you really?
Listen, Doctor, if Skagra has the Tardis and the book, he can get to Shada.
Shada? Shada?
Yes, the Time Lords' prison planet. You've probably forgotten about it.

I never forget anything. I never forget. Well, that's right. I have forgotten. The Time Lords' prison planet. Now why would I have forgotten? Got it. Of course! Salyavin was imprisoned on Shada. Yes. Ask me who Salyavin is.
Oh, now he was a great criminal imprisoned centuries ago by the Time Lords.
A great criminal. Unique mental powers. He had the ability to project his mind into other minds, completely take them over, didn't he, Professor?
That's what Skagra's doing?

Oh no, no, no, no, no. Quite the opposite. Skagra had the capacity to take minds out of people, but he can't put minds back into them. That's why he needs Salyavin in the sphere, and that's why he's going to Shada.
Of course!
Doctor! He must not get there.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Skagra allows the pages of the book to turn over one at a time, as the time rotor moves.

Dialogue.Line: The key turns slowly in the lock. The door to Shada opens.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Clare is pouring tea for everyone.

Dialogue.Line: With Skagra's mind and Salyavin's in the sphere, Skagra will be omnipotent.
What, you really mean he could just move himself into every mind in the universe?
Yes, eventually. It might take thousands of years, but that wouldn't matter. His mind's immortal. It would spread like a disease.
It's quite a thought though, isn't it? I mean, every mind working together as a single organism, a single mind.
Skagra's mind. Not a pleasant thought.
Doctor, we've got to stop him from getting to Shada.
Yes. But how? He's got a start on us and we don't know where it is.
Then we must follow him.
But how?
The same way as we arrived.
You followed the Tardis' space-time track. Of course! Of course. Let's go!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The prison is set into an asteroid. The Tardis materialises.

Dialogue.Line: Shada.
It looks horrid.
It was built by your race. A prison planet.
I hope you feel at home.
Keep her silent.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Skagra activates a console.

Dialogue.Line: The index. Ah. Chamber T, cabinet 9. Two of you guard this machine. You, bring the girl. Come.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Walking along.

Dialogue.Line: This is where your people used to put the criminals they wanted to forget.
I've never even heard of it.
Obviously you forgot. This way.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Meanwhile, a wooden door materialises.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor, we're arrived!
Good! Good! Now, you two CLARE + PARSONS: Yes?
Stay here.
Oh but
Shush. I am not at liberty to explain. K9, you can come along, but no tangling with any Krargs, unless of course if you have to tangle with any Krargs.
Hurry! Skagra will be here already. Come on.
Come on, K9. Come on. Come on.
The prisoners of Shada. Each in their own separate cryogenic cell. Alive, but frozen, in perpetual imprisonment. Very humane.
Don't look at me. I'm not answerable for the Time Lords.
You are a Time Lord.
Yes, but
No matter. The Time Lords will son be irrelevant. Before I find Salyavin, I think I shall release some of these. They can be the first to participate in the new universal mind.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Skagra works controls, and doors slide open. Various aliens wake up.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, it's odd the way some days work out, isn't it?
Chris.
I mean, there I was, just cycling down King's Parade
Chris, there's something very strange about the Professor.
Why single out the Professor?
Well, because when I was in
I want to know what's going on out there.
Chris, you're not listening to me.

I just don't like getting left behind. I mean, just because we come from Earth, it doesn't give everybody the right to be patronising towards us. Well, admittedly, all this does make us look a bit primitive. I mean, I haven't got the faintest idea how it all works.
I have.
Cabinet 9. Here he is. The man I've spent my whole life searching for. The man whose mind will reshape the entire universe. The great Salyavin. Let us release him.
Skagra, stop!
Doctor!
Keep away from here. You're too late. Salyavin is released.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The door slides open to reveal an empty cell.

Dialogue.Line: I don't understand. Salyavin. Where is Salyavin?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chronitis's eyes glow.

Dialogue.Line: You!
Let me just get this right. You say he just walked into your mind?
Well, sort of. It's as if he just barged in the front door and started shuffling all my thoughts about.
But the Doctor said that that ability was unique to the guy, well, the guy Skagra's come here to find. On your feet, Keightley. Come on, let's see what's happening. Shush.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Parsons and Clare go out into Shada.
K9 guns down a prisoner, but a Krarg drags Romana into the firing line.

Dialogue.Line: K9! K9: Master.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Krarg picks up K9 and throws him across the room.

Dialogue.Line: Run!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Romana ducks under the Krarg's arm, picks up K9 and runs out with the Doctor.

Dialogue.Line: I told you to stay in the room.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They run into Clare.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, but
Come on.
But Chris.
Come on, to the Tardis.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They run past the door, the Doctor changes his mind and goes inside.

Dialogue.Line: Quick, come in, come in. Come on, K9. Sit down!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: K9 is under his own power now. Romana and Clare sit quietly while the Doctor thinks for a few moments.

Dialogue.Line: Got it!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor goes into the Professor's bedroom, through the door that was originally hidden by the Doctor's Tardis.

Dialogue.Line: Well, what are we going to do?
So far he's beaten us on every point.
Yes, he's even got Chris.
Mmm.
Shush, shush. Quiet, I'm thinking.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor comes back in from the kitchen.

Dialogue.Line: I'm thinking, and it depresses me. Skagra's little zombie gang have got the brain power of the greatest intellects in the universe shared out among them. The Think Tank.
The who?

Never mind about that. Just believe me. All the minds that Skagra's stolen are now in the melting pot along with his own, and operating as one. And with the Professor's, I mean with Salyavin's mind in there too, they can now control anyone. They can control everyone. They'll be invincible.
Doctor?
Yes?
May I just remind you of something?
Yes.
All the minds that Skagra's stolen are in the melting pot.
Yes.
That means yours is in there too.
Yes! Romana?
Yes, Doctor?
Romana, I want you to do something for me. Stand there. Romana, I want you to wear this.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor pins a medal on Romana's blouse then kisses her on both cheeks. They salute each other.

Dialogue.Line: Well, now I can think.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Krargs, prisoners, Parsons and the spheres are all here.

Dialogue.Line: We will return to the carrier ship. From there a fleet of small craft will take each one of you to selected centres of population, and then the great mind revolution shall begin.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Tardis dematerialises.

Dialogue.Line: It'll be tricky.
And dangerous.
Well, a touch.
Doctor, it'll be terribly, terribly dangerous for you. You'll stand about as much chance as
As what?
As a. There isn't anything that stands as little chance as you will out there.
Well, I'll just have to be, I'll just have to be very brave, won't I.
Doctor, it isn't funny.
Listen, I can do your part if you can do mine.
I'll try.
You're a hero. Remember? Clare?
Yes, Doctor?
Hold on very tight.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Door appears in the Vortex next to the Tardis. The Doctor and Romana operate Chronotis's Tardis controls simultaneously.

Dialogue.Line: Ready?
Yes.
Clare?
Ready, Doctor.
Hold tight. Now!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A green light reaches out from the Door to the Tardis

Dialogue.Line: Ha ha! Got them. Well done, Romana.
We haven't got to the hard bit yet.
No, we haven't got long. Clare?
Yes, Doctor, I'm holding on.
Come over here and hold on to this, then.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Clare takes hold of the very long lever.

Dialogue.Line: And whatever you do, don't let go, because we are in for a very, very rough ride.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A short time later.

Dialogue.Line: And twenty thirdly, out there in the space-time vortex, time and distance have no meaning, but here in this little, little room
Oh, get on with it, Doctor!
Romana?
Yes, Doctor?
I want you to switch off the vortex shields in this small area here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He indicates somewhere near the kitchen with the toasting fork.

Dialogue.Line: Come on, you can do it. I showed you how to do it. Just one little bit of timelessness and spacelessness over there behind the tea trolley.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Romana makes careful adjustments. The area wibbles and the tea trolley rolls across the floor.

Dialogue.Line: I said behind the tea trolley, not in the middle of it.
I'm sorry, but it's very difficult.
Focus it! Now just one steady line, eh? One. Steady. Hold it. Hold it!
I'm trying, Doctor. I'm trying!
Phew. Right. Now this is a little trick I learnt from a space-time mystic in the Quantocks. He made it seem very, very easy.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor walks forward and vanishes.

Dialogue.Line: Oh! He did it!
Hold that switch down!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is crawling through the green light between the two time capsules.

Dialogue.Line: It won't hold much longer. It's fading even faster than the Doctor said it would. K9. K9, wake up and come here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Clare and Romana swap levers so that Romana can open the cupboard underneath the console.

Dialogue.Line: Check out the subneutron circuits. K9: Detect circuit malfunction, mistress.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is nearly at the Tardis.

Dialogue.Line: Impossible to effect repair in time available, mistress.
Well, hold it, K9. Stop it deteriorating. K9: Impossible to stop it, mistress. I can only slow down circuit deterioration.
The Doctor needs every second we can give him.
This switch is getting very hot.
You must hold it down.
But I can't. It's getting hotter.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is starting to to slide backwards.

Dialogue.Line: It's burning me.
Oh, hold it down with a pencil.
But I haven't got one.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Romana tries to reach one on a pile of papers whilst hanging on to the long lever.

Dialogue.Line: I can't reach it.
Oh. Well, here, hold this.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Clare releases her switch and the console goes bang! The girls are thrown across the room.

Dialogue.Line: It's broken.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The link between the time machines is gone. They whirl off through the Vortex, and so does the Doctor. Romana bandages Clare's burnt hand.

Dialogue.Line: What about the Doctor?
I don't know. It was a very dangerous idea trying to make that crossing. He didn't get as much time as he wanted. I just don't know.
What should we do?
Well, we'll just go ahead as planned. There. How's that?
Oh, it's fine, thank you. It wasn't a bad burn. Look, do you think the Doctor will be all right?
We'll just go ahead as planned. K9: Repairs completed, mistress.
Let me see. Good boy, K9. Now we can go. Though I dread to think what we're walking into if. Oh, well, let's just do it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor tumbles into a room. There are racks of odds and ends against the wall, including a Cyberman's head. He starts to collect bits and pieces.

Dialogue.Line: Good. Good. Good.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Tardis materialises.

Dialogue.Line: And soon, an infinite consort of the mind.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor sneaks into the console room with a helmet device he has made in his own workshop.

Dialogue.Line: Hello, old girl. How've you been keeping? Sorry I had to barge in through your back door like that, but if you had any idea what it's like to travel through the Space-Time Vortex... Ha, ha, of course you do. Silly me. You do it all the time. But at least you're built for it. Now, let's see what's happening outside, shall we?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The scanner shows Skagra and his crew standing outside the Door to Chronotis's Tardis.

Dialogue.Line: Look out behind you! Let's go and say hello.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor opens the Tardis doors and blows on a dog whistle.

Dialogue.Line: Out you come, Doctor. Out you come.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Door opens with a creak and K9 comes out.

Dialogue.Line: He sends his dog out to face me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor comes out of the Tardis and walks up behind Skagra.

Dialogue.Line: Stop hiding in there, Doctor. Come out and meet your fate.
Hello.
Doctor! How did you get in there?
What do you mean, how did I get in there. It's mine, I belong in there.
As of now, Doctor, you don't belong anywhere at all. There is no place for you in my universe. You shall die.
Well, Skagra, that's a very interesting theory. (puts on helmet) Let's try putting it to the test, shall we?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He turns the helmet on and stares at Skagra. The prisoners also stare at Skagra.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor, what have you done?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The prisoners advance on Skagra. He concentrates hard and they turn towards the Doctor.

Dialogue.Line: No, what have you done? You've used that deranged billiard ball once too often. You forget, there's a copy of my brain in there too, eh? Think about it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The prisoners advance on Skagra again, then get a little confused.

Dialogue.Line: But not too hard, old chap. You might strain yourself. A new universe, a new single mind. Ha. I think your little bunch are in two minds about that one already.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Skagra clicks his fingers and a Krarg moves towards the Doctor. The Doctor is blocked by the prisoners.

Dialogue.Line: K9! K9: Master.
Fire!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: K9's laser heats up the Krarg.

Dialogue.Line: Now, lay on, Skagra. Let's see the quality of your mind.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The two men concentrate.

Dialogue.Line: A little warm for the time of year, wouldn't you say, Skagra? Off, K9.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The super-heated Krarg staggers backwards.

Dialogue.Line: Not that way. The other way, you fool. The other way! Back!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two more Krarg approach K9 from the rear.

K9 turns and heats them up too. The first Krarg has entered the chamber where it was first created. Romana pushes it into a vat, where it sizzles. Then she stands one of the other vats upright and pulls two wires from the wall.

Dialogue.Line: Clare! Clare!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Clare opens the Door as the prisoners back the Doctor up against a wall. Romana talks to her behind Skagra's back.

Dialogue.Line: K9, stop firing.
Now!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Clare and Romana drop the live wires onto the floor. The electricity surges through the hot Krarg and they explode. The Doctor gets the prisoners to move on Skagra again.

Dialogue.Line: You want to call half-time, Skagra? You can have a short break if you like, suck a lemon. Perk you up no end.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Skagra runs for his life.

Dialogue.Line: Ship! Take off instantly. Instantly, do you hear? Instantly!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The cube appears and he vanishes. Back in the main area, Parsons wakes up.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor, look out! Doctor. Where am I? CLARE: It's all right. It's all right, Chris. It's over. Everything's going to be all right.
Clare?
How are the others?
They're all in shock, but there's no serious damage.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor kicks a defunct sphere.

Dialogue.Line: I hate to think what would have happened to them if that tug-of-war had carried on much longer.
They wouldn't have been the only ones in trouble. This is a fearful mess.
Can you unscramble them all?
Oh. Yes. It'll take a few hours, but they'll all get their own minds back.
What'll you do with them then?
Take them back to dear old Shada.
Put them back in a forgotten prison?

Let the Time Lords sort it out. I'm not going to play judge and jury. It was only forgotten about because the Professor made us forget. He didn't want his escape to be discovered. That must be why he stole the book when he left Gallifrey.
Do you suppose he's still alive?
Well, we'll find out.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He puts two halves of a sphere together and tosses it over his shoulder.
The cube deposits Skagra into the room on the spacecraft where he had previously imprisoned the Doctor, Parsons and K9. He looks rather small here.

Dialogue.Line: Ship! Let me out of here. I am your Lord Skagra. Let me out!
